claim: GTM belongs to the CEO; it is iterative like a product, not a one-time project.
rationale: CEO ownership prevents ambiguity and silos; GTM needs constant refinement with tracked 'bugs'.

claim: Focus on Total Relevant Market (TRM) not TAM—best-fit target accounts first.
rationale: Broad TAM is inefficient; starting small refines PMF and renewals before expanding.

claim: RevOps is the growth lever and truth-teller; should report to a neutral exec.
rationale: Centralized RevOps prevents conflicting numbers and aligns incentives across GTM.

claim: Retention is the new acquisition; LTV is the primary KPI.
rationale: Low churn drives ARR; aim for negative churn where expansions outpace churn.

claim: Replace leaky lead funnels with revenue flywheels focused on quality accounts and success.
rationale: <1% of leads become loyal in funnels; flywheels build momentum via customer success.

claim: GTM maturity stages: Ideation (Problem-Market Fit) → Transition (Product-Market Fit) → Execution (Platform-Market Fit).
rationale: Each stage needs different metrics, stack, and org; revenue alone doesn’t define stage.

claim: Scaling without clear ICP stalls/crashes; heroics and volume can’t sustain growth.
rationale: Ideation relies on high outbound for learning; becomes untenable without ICP definition.

claim: Heavy discounting/renewing down signals weak PMF and blocks stage transition.
rationale: Erodes margins and shows lack of differentiated value; stalls sustainable growth.

claim: Heroic, non-repeatable sales prevent scaling past ideation.
rationale: Without repeatable processes/playbooks, adding reps fails; growth caps at hero capacity.

claim: Misaligned promises: selling what product can’t deliver breaks GTM and damages trust.
rationale: Churn and bad references block PMF; sales must match delivery reality.

claim: Velocity depends on people ramp + enablement ramp; hire ahead using RevOps data.
rationale: Without enablement, scaling burns out teams and hurts customers; proactive hiring beats reactive.

claim: Three expansion vectors: Sales (partners/channels), Coverage (GEOs/verticals/up/down-market), Solutions (multi-product).
rationale: Answering MOVE questions enables expansion; sales expansion can deliver nonlinear growth.

claim: HubSpot drove ~40% revenue via partners (referral/channel/agency), enabling nonlinear growth.
rationale: Partner ecosystem reduced CAC and reliance on direct sales hiring.

claim: Zoom expanded coverage into B2C/nonprofits/government during COVID, leveraging existing platform.
rationale: Coverage expansion captured new segments fast when market shift aligned.

claim: Salesforce moved upmarket from SMB to enterprise, expanding coverage to larger budgets/needs.
rationale: Upmarket coverage shift transformed it into an enterprise platform leader.
